If for some of the transformations, $\epsilon^\mu = k^\mu$, the metric tensor does not change,
i.e.

\begin{eqnarray}
D^{(\mu} k^{\nu)} \equiv D^\mu k^\nu + D^\nu k^\mu = 0,
\end{eqnarray}
then the corresponding vector field, $k^\mu$, is referred to as \underline{Killing vector} and the transformations are called \underline{isometries} of the metric. For example, the Schwarzschild metric tensor does not depend on time, $t$, and angle, $\varphi$. Hence, it's isometries include at least the translations in time
$t \to t + a$ and rotations $\varphi \to \varphi + b$, for some constants $a$ and $b$. The corresponding Killing vectors, $k^\mu = \left(k^t, k^r, k^\theta, k^\varphi\right)$, have the following form: $k^\mu = (1,0,0,0)$ and $k^\mu = (0,0,0,1)$.
